Consider including *all* languages in the index?

According to the Generic Style Rules, 16.6, all names should be Last, First. This is different from the USL rules this entry seems to follow, cf. footnote 19 in the GSR. If references are supposed to follow the USL instead of GSR, that should be noted in the proofreading guidelines.
Only very few entries in the bibliography have DOIs, even though more DOIs are available (eg. 10.2307/415537 for the first entry). Several entries have DOI:\biberror{??}

According to Unified Style Sheet for Linguistics, this shoud probably be ‘Robert D. Van Valin, Jr.’; according to the Generic Style Rules, this would be ‘Van Valin, Robert D., Jr.’ (cf. note above concerning USL/GSR discrepancy)
Typographically, this should be an en-dash, not a hyphen.
According to GSR, this should be 'University of Texas (MA thesis)' instead.

column8: not the patterns themselves

This footnote looks like an objection (or at least some kind of concession) to the claim that cross-linguistic comparison only deals with systems. But you don't make this claim in the main text. As far as I understand section 2.1, 'regularities' may refer to both system and use. Do you need this footnote at all?

I think I understand what you mean (that recurrent patterns are neither universal nor prevailing), but the wording 'any kind' is misleading, since in this very sentence you are talking about frequency, which is a quantitative claim by definition.

That representational constraints can be weaker preferences (more general) or that there is a weak innate preference to put elements into a 'determiner' category (more specific)? [I don't really understand what the latter means, actually].

I think Levshina actually shows that they do, but maybe you are considering the literature she is citing to belong to  cognitive science rather than linguistics. But I'm probably going beyond the proofreader's role here anyway.

column8: For instance, first time you use one of these glosses

This wording implies that functional-adaptive approach assumes that change processes have a goal. But they don't: there's no 'goal' in evolution (there are pull forces, selection, attractor states etc.)
Otherwise the reader gets the expression that you are explaining 'staying' rather than 'evolutionary time'. Say e.g. 'the total amount of time over...'
